## ABSTRACT

This paper undertakes a thorough investigation of matrix means interpolation and comparison. We expand the parameter $\vartheta$ beyond the closed interval $[0,1]$ to cover the entire positive real line, denoted as $\mathbb{R}^{+}$. Furthermore, we explore additional outcomes related to Heinz means. We introduce new scalar adaptations of Heinz inequalities, incorporating Kantorovich's constant, and enhance the operator version. Finally, we unveil refined Young's type inequalities designed specifically for traces, determinants, and norms of positive semi-definite matrices.

Keywords Heinz mean inequalities $\cdot$ positive semi-definite matrices $\cdot$ Hilbert-Schmidt norm $\cdot$ Young inequality

## 1 Introduction

Consider the algebra of complex matrices of size $n \times n$, denoted as $M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$. A matrix $T$ in $M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ is considered positive semi-definite, written as $T \geq 0$, if it is Hermitian and satisfies $\langle T x, x\rangle \geq 0$ for all vectors $x$ in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. If, for a Hermitian matrix $T$ in $M_{n}(\mathbb{C}),\langle T x, x\rangle>0$ holds for all nonzero vectors $x$ in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$, it is termed a positive definite matrix, denoted as $T>0$. The set of all positive matrices is denoted as $M_{n}^{+}(\mathbb{C})$, and the subset of definite matrices within $M_{n}^{+}(\mathbb{C})$ is represented as $M_{n}^{++}(\mathbb{C})$. The Schur product of two matrices $T=\left[t_{i j}\right]_{i, j}$ and $S=\left[s_{i j}\right]_{i, j}$ in $M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ is defined as the matrix $T \circ S$ with entries $t_{i j} s_{i j}$. A norm $\|\mid\|$ on the set of complex matrices of size $n \times n$, denoted as $M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$, is termed unitarily invariant if $\|U A V\|=\|T\| \|$ for any matrix $T$ in $M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ and for all unitary matrices $U$ and $V$ in $M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$.
For a matrix $T=\left[t_{i j}\right] \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$, the Hilbert-Schmidt norm (also known as the Frobenius norm) and the trace norm of $T$ are defined as follows

$$
\|T\|_{2}=\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}^{2}(T)\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}, \quad\|T\|_{1}=\operatorname{tr}(|T|)=\sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}(T)
$$

Here, $s_{1}(T) \geq s_{2}(T) \geq \cdots \geq s_{n}(T) \geq 0$ represent the singular values of $T$, which are the eigenvalues of the positive matrix $|T|=\sqrt{T^{*} T}$ arranged in decreasing order and repeated according to multiplicity. The symbol $\operatorname{tr}($.$) denotes the$ usual trace operation.
It's important to note that the mathematical norms $\|\cdot\|_{2}$ and $\|\cdot\|_{1}$ are widely recognized for being unitarily invariant.
The classic Young's inequality for non-negative real numbers states that if $\rho, \sigma \geq 0$ and $0 \leq \kappa \leq 1$, then

$$
\rho^{\kappa} \sigma^{1-\kappa} \leq \kappa \rho+(1-\kappa) \sigma
$$

Equality occurs if and only if $\rho=\sigma$. When $\kappa$ is $\frac{1}{2}$, substituting into the inequality yields the arithmetic-geometric mean inequality

$$
\sqrt{\rho \sigma} \leq \frac{\rho+\sigma}{2}
$$

Manasarah and Kittaneh, as presented in Kittaneh and Manasrah [2010], improved Young's inequality with the following refinement

$$
\left(\rho^{\kappa} \sigma^{1-\kappa}\right)^{m}+r_{0}^{m}\left(\rho^{\frac{m}{2}}-\sigma^{\frac{m}{2}}\right)^{2} \leq\left(\kappa \rho^{r}+(1-\kappa) \sigma^{r}\right)^{\frac{m}{r}}, \quad r \geq 1
$$

where $m \in \mathbb{N}$ and $r_{0}=\min \{\kappa, 1-\kappa\}$.
The Kantorovich constant, denoted as $K(t, 2)$, is defined as $\frac{(t+1)^{2}}{4 t}$. It possesses several key properties: $K(1,2)=1$, $K(t, 2)=K\left(\frac{1}{t}, 2\right) \geq 1(t>0)$ and $K(t, 2)$ is monotone increasing on $[1, \infty)$, and monotone decreasing on $(0,1]$. For more detailed information about the Kantorovich constant, interested readers can refer to Nasiri and Shakoori [2016], Rashid and Bani-Ahmad [2023], liang Zuo et al. [2011], Zhang and Wu [2017]..
The following multiplicative refinement and reversal of Young's inequality, expressed in terms of Kantorovich's constant, can be stated as follows

$$
K(h, 2)^{r} \rho_{\# \kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma \leq \rho \nabla_{\kappa} \sigma \leq K(h, 2)^{R} \rho_{\# \kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma
$$

where $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are both greater than $0, \kappa$ belongs to the interval $[0,1], r$ is the minimum of $\kappa$ and $1-\kappa, R$ is the maximum of $\kappa$ and $1-\kappa$, and $h$ is defined as $\frac{\sigma}{\rho}$.
The second inequality in (5) is credited to Liao et al. Liao et al. [2015], while the first one is attributed to Zou et al. liang Zuo et al. [2011]. In Wu and Zhao [2014], the authors obtained another improvement of the Young inequality and its reverse as follows:

$$
r(\sqrt{\rho}-\sqrt{\sigma})^{2}+K(\sqrt{h}, 2)^{r^{\prime}} \rho_{\# \kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma \leq \rho \nabla_{\kappa} \sigma
$$

and

$$
\rho \nabla_{\kappa} \sigma \leq K(\sqrt{h}, 2)^{-r^{\prime}} \rho_{\# \kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma+R(\sqrt{\rho}-\sqrt{\sigma})^{2}
$$

where $h=\frac{\sigma}{\rho}, r=\min \{\kappa, 1-\kappa\}, R=\max \{\kappa, 1-\kappa\}$ and $r^{\prime}=\min \{2 r, 1-2 r\}$. In addition, another kind of the reversal of Young inequality utilizing Kantorovich's constant is described in Liao et al. [2015] with the same notation as above.

$$
\rho \nabla_{\kappa} \sigma-R(\sqrt{\rho}-\sqrt{\sigma})^{2} \leq K(\sqrt{h}, 2)^{R^{\prime}} \rho_{\# \kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma
$$

where $R^{\prime}=\max \{2 r, 1-2 r\}$.
For $\kappa$ in the range of $[0,1]$ and two non-negative real numbers $\rho$ and $\sigma$, the Heinz mean serves as an interpolation between the $\kappa$-arithmetic mean and the $\kappa$-geometric mean. These are defined by the expression

$$
H_{\kappa}(\rho, \sigma)=\frac{\rho_{\# \kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma+\rho_{\# 1-\kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma}{2}
$$

where $\rho_{\# \kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma=\rho^{\kappa} \sigma^{1-\kappa}$ represents the $\kappa$-geometric mean.
The Heinz mean possesses certain properties, including convexity concerning $\kappa$ within the interval $[0,1]$. Its minimum occurs at $\kappa=\frac{1}{2}$, and its maximum values are found at $\kappa=0$ and $\kappa=1$. Additionally, the following inequalities are true

$$
\sqrt{\rho \sigma} \leq H_{\kappa}(\rho, \sigma) \leq \frac{\rho+\sigma}{2}
$$

It is worth noting that the function $H_{\kappa}(\rho, \sigma)$ exhibits symmetry with respect to the point $\kappa=\frac{1}{2}$, meaning that $H_{\kappa}(\rho, \sigma)=H_{1-\kappa}(\rho, \sigma)$.

The Heron mean is defined by the expression

$$
F_{\vartheta}(\rho, \sigma)=(1-\vartheta) \sqrt{\rho \sigma}+\vartheta\left(\frac{\rho+\sigma}{2}\right), \vartheta \in[0,1] \text { and } \rho, \sigma \in \mathbb{R}^{+}
$$

where $\vartheta$ takes values in the interval $[0,1]$, and $\rho$ and $\sigma$ are positive real numbers.
Evidently, the Heron mean serves as a linear interpolation between the arithmetic and geometric means. It adheres to the inequality $F_{\vartheta} \leq F_{\varrho}$ whenever $\vartheta \leq \varrho$, with both $\vartheta$ and $\varrho$ belonging to the positive real numbers.

In a study by Bhatia published in Bhatia [2006], it was demonstrated that for $\vartheta(\kappa)=(2 \kappa-1)^{2}$ and $\kappa$ within the range of $[0,1]$, the following relation holds

$$
H_{\kappa}(\rho, \sigma) \leq F_{\vartheta(\kappa)}(\rho, \sigma)
$$

Our paper is structured as follows: In the upcoming section, we will conduct an in-depth investigation into matrix interpolation and mean comparisons. This analysis extends the scope of $\vartheta$ beyond the closed interval $[0,1]$ to include all positive real numbers, represented as $\mathbb{R}^{+}$. Additionally, we will explore additional findings pertaining to Heinz means. Section three is dedicated to exploring refinements in Heinz inequality, incorporating the Kantorovich constant. Section 4 focuses on examining enhanced variations of Heinz-type operator inequalities and their corresponding reversals. Finally, in section 5, we present refined inequalities of Young's type, specifically designed for traces, determinants, and norms of positive semi-definite matrices.

# 2 Full Interpolation of Matrix Variants of Heron and Heinz MEANS 

In the paper referenced as Bhatia [2006], R. Bhatia established a noteworthy result. In particular, it was shown that for values of $\vartheta$ in the interval $[0,1 / 2]$, the function $\psi(\vartheta)$ adheres to the inequality $\psi(\vartheta) \leq \psi(1 / 2)$. Here, $\psi(\vartheta)$ denotes one of the potential matrix formulations of Equation (11), and its definition is as follows

$$
\psi(\vartheta)=\left\|\left((1-\vartheta) T^{1 / 2} X S^{1 / 2}+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|\right\|
$$

This definition involves matrices $T, S$, and $X$, subject to the conditions that $T$ and $S$ belong to the set of positive definite matrices in $\mathbb{C}$, denoted as $M_{n}^{++}(\mathbb{C})$, and $X$ is a member of the set of $n \times n$ matrices over $\mathbb{C}$, denoted as $M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$.
For further insights into the matrix formulations of Equation (9) and Equation (12), as well as additional details, interested readers are encouraged to refer to the following references: Bhatia [2006], R.A. Horn [1985], R.A. Horn [1990], Hiai and Kosaki [1999], and Kaur and Singh [2011].
Within the context of this article, the author endeavors to demonstrate that for $\vartheta$ values within the interval $[0,1 / 2]$, the function $\psi(\vartheta, \kappa)$ adheres to the inequality $\psi(\vartheta, \kappa) \leq \psi(1 / 2, \kappa)$. Additionally, it is asserted that $\psi(\vartheta, \kappa)$ displays an increasing trend as $\vartheta$ varies within the range $[1 / 2, \infty)$.
This result serves as a generalization of the previously established monotonic property associated with the matrix version of Equation (11). This generalization mirrors the behavior of $F_{\vartheta}(\rho, \sigma)$ for positive real numbers $a$ and $b$ when $\vartheta$ belongs to the set of positive real numbers, $\mathbb{R}^{+}$.
As a consequential outcome of these findings, the author will introduce a potential generalized matrix equivalent of Equation (12), which can be expressed as follows

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left\|\mid T^{\mu} X S^{1-\mu}+T^{1-\mu} X S^{\mu}\right\| \leq\left\|\left((1-\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|\right\|
$$

This inequality is valid for particular values of $\mu \in[1 / 4,3 / 4], \kappa \in[0,1]$, and $\vartheta \in[1 / 2, \infty)$.
In this section, we will undertake a thorough investigation of matrix interpolation and mean comparisons. This scrutiny broadens the range of $\vartheta$ from the closed interval $[0,1]$ to encompass the entirety of positive real numbers, denoted as $\mathbb{R}^{+}$. Furthermore, we will delve into additional findings associated with Heinz means.
Theorem 2.1. R.A. Horn [1990] Let $T, S \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ such that $T$ is a positive semi-definite. Then

$$
\|T \circ S\| \leq \max _{1 \leq i \leq n} t_{i i}\|S\| \|
$$

where $t_{i i}$ for $i=1,2, \cdots, n$ are the diagonal entries of matrix $T$.
Lemma 2.2. Zhan [2002] Let $\kappa_{1}, \kappa_{2}, \cdots, \kappa_{n}$ be positive numbers, $r \in[-1,1]$, and $t \in(-2,2]$. Then the $n \times n$ matrix matrix

$$
\Gamma=\left(\frac{\kappa_{i}^{r}+\kappa_{j}^{r}}{\kappa_{i}^{2}+t \kappa_{i} \kappa_{j}+\kappa_{j}^{2}}\right)
$$

is positive semi-definite.

Theorem 2.3. Let $T, S, X \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ such that $T$ and $S$ are positive semi-definite, $\kappa \in[0,1]$ and $\|\mid$.\| any unitarily invariant norm, the function

$$
\psi(\vartheta, \kappa)=\left\|\mid(1-\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|
$$

is increasing for $\frac{1}{2} \leq \vartheta<\infty$ and $\psi(\vartheta, \kappa) \leq \psi\left(\frac{1}{2}, \kappa\right)$ for all $\vartheta \in\left[0, \frac{1}{2}\right]$.

Proof. We first prove the result for $\vartheta>0$ and $T=S$, that is,

$$
\left\|\mid(1-\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|=\frac{\vartheta}{2} Z(\vartheta)
$$

where $Z(\vartheta)=\left\|\mid Q(\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X T^{1-\kappa}+T X+X T\right\| \mid$ and $Q(\vartheta)=2\left(\frac{1}{\vartheta}-1\right)$. We may assume without loss of generality, $T=\operatorname{diag}\left(\eta_{1}, \cdots, \eta_{n}\right), \eta_{j}>0$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q(\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X T^{1-\kappa}+T X+X T=\left(\left(Q(\vartheta) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}\right) x_{i j}\right)_{i, j} \\
& =\left(\frac{Q(\vartheta) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}{Q(\varrho) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}\right)_{i, j} \circ\left(Q(\varrho) T^{\kappa} X T^{1-\kappa}+T X+X T\right) \\
& =E \circ\left(Q(\varrho) T^{\kappa} X T^{1-\kappa}+T X+X T\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $E=\left(\frac{Q(\vartheta) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}{Q(\varrho) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}\right)_{i, j}$. Now the matrix $E$ can be written as

$$
\left(1+\frac{(Q(\vartheta)-Q(\varrho)) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}}{Q(\varrho) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}\right)=(1)_{i, j}+\left(\eta_{i}^{\kappa}\left(\frac{Q(\vartheta)-Q(\varrho)}{Q(\varrho) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}\right) \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}\right)
$$

which will be positive semidefinite if the matrix,

$$
G=\left(\frac{Q(\vartheta)-Q(\varrho)}{Q(\varrho) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}\right)_{i, j}
$$

is positive semidefinite. According to Lemma 2.2, the latter matrix is positive semidefinite if and only if $Q(\vartheta) \geq Q(\varrho)$ and $Q(\varrho) \in[-2,2]$. Since $Q(\vartheta)=2\left(\frac{1}{\vartheta}-1\right)$ is a continuous and decreasing function on the positive half-line, ranging from $\left[\frac{1}{2}, \infty\right)$ into $[-2,2]$, it follows that $Q(\vartheta) \geq Q(\varrho)$ for all $\varrho \geq \vartheta$. Consequently, using Theorem 2.1, we can deduce that $Z(\vartheta) \leq\left(\frac{Q(\vartheta)+2}{Q(\varrho)+2}\right) T(\varrho)$. Thus, the result holds for $T=S$ and $\vartheta \geq \frac{1}{2}$.

For $\vartheta \in(0,1 / 2]$, we have $2 \leq Q(\vartheta)<\infty$, and $Q(\vartheta)>Q\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=2$. Therefore, the matrix $E$ with $\varrho=\frac{1}{2}$ is positive semidefinite, as per Lemma 2.1. The case $\vartheta=0$ is straightforward since, by Lemma 2.1, the matrix

$$
\left(\frac{\eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}}{\eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}\right)_{i, j}=\left(\eta_{i}^{\kappa}\left(\frac{1}{\eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}}\right) \eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}\right)_{i, j}
$$

is positive semidefinite. Thus, we have established the desired result for this case, i.e., $\vartheta Z(\vartheta) \leq \frac{1}{2} Z\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)$. In other words, $\psi(\vartheta, \kappa) \leq \psi\left(\frac{1}{2}, \kappa\right)$ for all $\vartheta \in[0,1 / 2]$. The general case can be derived by substituting $T$ with $\left(\begin{array}{cc}T & 0 \\ 0 & S\end{array}\right)$ and $X$ by $\left(\begin{array}{cc}X & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)$.

Remark 2.4. By setting $\kappa$ to be equal to half (i.e., $\kappa=\frac{1}{2}$ ) in Theorem 2.3, we can deduce that we arrive at Theorem 2.3 as presented in Kaur and Singh [2011]. Consequently, our findings represent an enhancement of the results established in that theorem.

As a consequence of Theorem 2.3, we have
Corollary 2.5. Let $T, S, X \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ with $T, S$ positive definite. Then for any unitarily invariant norm $\|\cdot\|$ and a matrix monotone increasing function $\psi:(0, \infty) \longrightarrow(0, \infty)$ with $\psi^{*}(x)=x(\psi(x))^{-1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{2}\left\|\mid T^{\frac{\mu}{2}}\left(\psi\left(T^{\mu}\right) X \psi^{*}\left(S^{\mu}\right)+\psi^{*}\left(T^{\mu}\right) X \psi\left(S^{\mu}\right)\right) S^{\frac{\mu}{2}}\right\| \\
& \leq\left\|\mid(1-\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

Corollary 2.6. Let $T, S, X \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ with $T, S$ positive definite. Then for any unitarily invariant norm $\|\cdot\|, \frac{1}{4} \leq \mu \leq$ $\frac{3}{4}, \kappa \in[0,1]$ and $\vartheta \in[1 / 2, \infty)$,

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left\|\mid T^{\mu} X S^{1-\mu}+T^{1-\mu} X S^{\mu}\right\| \leq\left\|\mid(1-\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|
$$

Proof. Letting $\psi(x)=\sqrt{x}$ in Corollary 2.5, we derived the result.
The following result is a consequence of Theorem 2.3.
Corollary 2.7. Let $T, S, X \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ with $T, S$ positive definite, $\eta=\min \{s p(T), s p(S)\}, \mu \in[1 / 4,3 / 4]$ and $\kappa \in[0,1]$. Then for any unitarily invariant norm $\|\cdot\|$ and a matrix monotone increasing function $\psi:(0, \infty) \longrightarrow(0, \infty)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\eta}{2 f(\eta)}\left\|\mid T^{\frac{\mu}{2}}\left(\psi\left(T^{\mu}\right) X+X \psi\left(S^{\mu}\right)\right) S^{\frac{\mu}{2}}\right\| \\
& \leq\left\|\mid(1-\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

holds for every $\vartheta \in[1 / 2, \infty)$.
Choosing $\psi(x)=\log (1+x)$ in Corollary 2.7, we have
Corollary 2.8. Let $T, S, X \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ with $T, S$ positive definite, $\eta=\min \{s p(T), s p(S)\}, \mu \in[1 / 4,3 / 4]$ and $\kappa \in[0,1]$. Then for any unitarily invariant norm $\|\cdot\|$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\eta}{2 \log (1+\eta)}\left\|\mid T^{\frac{\mu}{2}}\left(\log \left(1+T^{\mu}\right) X+X \log \left(1+S^{\mu}\right)\right) S^{\frac{\mu}{2}}\right\| \\
& \leq\left\|\mid(1-\vartheta) T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

holds for every $\vartheta \in[1 / 2, \infty)$.
Theorem 2.9. Consider $T, S, X \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ with $T$ and $S$ being positive definite, $\kappa \in[0,1]$, and $\|\cdot\|$ denoting any unitarily invariant norm. The function can be expressed as:

$$
\phi(\vartheta, \kappa)=\left\|\mid\left(1-\frac{\vartheta}{2}\right)\left(T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+T^{1-\kappa} X S^{\kappa}\right)+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X S}{2}\right)\right\|
$$

is increasing for $\frac{1}{2} \leq \vartheta<\infty$ and $\phi(\vartheta, \kappa) \leq \phi\left(\frac{1}{2}, \kappa\right)$ for all $\vartheta \in\left[0, \frac{1}{2}\right]$.
Proof. Once again following the same lines of the proof of Theorem (2.3), we shall prove the result for $\vartheta>0, T=S$ and $T=\operatorname{diag}\left(\eta_{1}, \cdots, \eta_{n}\right)$. Suppose

$$
\phi(\vartheta, \kappa)=\left\|\mid\left(1-\frac{\vartheta}{2}\right)\left(T^{\kappa} X T^{1-\kappa}+T^{1-\kappa} X T^{\kappa}\right)+\vartheta\left(\frac{T X+X T}{2}\right)\right\|=\frac{\vartheta}{2} Z(\vartheta, \kappa)
$$

where $Z(\vartheta, \kappa)=\left\|\left\|W_{1}(\vartheta)\left(T^{\kappa} X T^{1-\kappa}+T^{1-\kappa} X T^{\kappa}\right)+(T X+X T)\right\|\right\|$ and $W_{1}(\vartheta)=\frac{2}{\vartheta}-1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& W_{1}(\vartheta)\left(T^{\kappa} X T^{1-\kappa}+T^{1-\kappa} X T^{\kappa}\right)+(T X+X T) \\
& =\left[\left(W_{1}(\vartheta)\left(\eta_{i}^{\mu} \eta_{j}^{1-\mu}+\eta_{i}^{1-\mu} \eta_{j}^{\mu}\right)+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}\right) x_{i j}\right]_{i, j} \\
& =Y \circ\left(W_{1}(\varrho)\left(T^{\kappa} X T^{1-\kappa}+T^{1-\kappa} X T^{\kappa}\right)+T X+X S\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now the matrix $Y$ can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\begin{array}{l}
W_{1}(\vartheta)\left(\eta_{i}^{\mu} \eta_{j}^{1-\mu}+\eta_{i}^{1-\mu} \eta_{j}^{\mu}\right)+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j} \\
W_{1}(\varrho)\left(\eta_{i}^{\mu} \eta_{j}^{1-\mu}+\eta_{i}^{1-\mu} \eta_{j}^{\mu}\right)+\eta_{i}+\eta_{j}
\end{array}\right)_{i, j}=\left(1+\frac{\left(W_{1}(\vartheta)-W_{1}(\varrho)\right) \eta_{i}^{\mu} \eta_{j}^{\kappa}}{\left(W_{1}(\varrho)-1\right) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{\kappa}+\eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}}\right)_{i, j} \\
& =(1)_{i, j}+\left(\eta_{i}^{\kappa}\left(\frac{W_{1}(\vartheta)-W_{1}(\varrho)}{\left(W_{1}(\varrho)-1\right) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{\kappa}+\eta_{i}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}}\right) \eta_{j}^{\mu}\right)_{i, j}
\end{aligned}
$$

Once again, considering Lemma (2.2), we observe that the latter matrix is positive semidefinite if and only if $W_{1}(\vartheta)>$ $W_{1}(\varrho)$ and $2>W_{1}(\varrho)-1>-2$. Since $W(\vartheta)=W_{1}(\vartheta)-1=\left(2 \vartheta^{-1}-2\right)$, it is a continuously decreasing function in the positive half-line and maps to the interval $(-2,2]$ for $\vartheta$ in the range $[1 / 2, \infty)$. Therefore, as demonstrated in Theorem (2.3), we can deduce that $W(\vartheta)>W(\varrho)$ and consequently, $W_{1}(\vartheta)>W_{1}(\varrho)$ for all $\vartheta \leq \varrho$.

Applying Theorem (2.1), we establish that $T(\vartheta, \kappa) \leq \frac{W_{1}(\vartheta)+1}{W_{1}(\varrho)+1} T(\varrho, \kappa)$. This verifies the result for the case when $T=S$ and $\vartheta \in[1 / 2, \infty)$.
For $\vartheta \in(0,1 / 2]$, we can observe that $3=W_{1}(1 / 2) \leq W_{1}(\vartheta)<\infty$, and according to Lemma (2.2), the matrix $Y$ with $\varrho=1 / 2$ is positive semidefinite. Similarly, the case $\vartheta=0$ can be established through the positive semidefiniteness of the matrix $\left(\eta_{i}^{\kappa}\left(\frac{W_{1}(\vartheta)-W_{1}(\varrho)}{\left(W_{1}(\varrho)-1\right) \eta_{i}^{\kappa} \eta_{j}^{\kappa}+\eta_{i}^{1-\kappa}+\eta_{j}^{1-\kappa}}\right) \eta_{j}^{\mu}\right)_{i, j}$, which is confirmed by utilizing Lemma (2.2). This leads us to the desired result for this case, i.e., $\vartheta Z(\vartheta, \kappa) \leq \frac{1}{2} Z\left(\frac{1}{2}, \kappa\right)$. In other words, $\phi(\vartheta, \kappa) \leq \phi(1 / 2, \kappa)$ holds for all $\vartheta \in[0,1 / 2]$.

The general case can be obtained by substituting $T$ with $\left(\begin{array}{ll}T & 0 \\ 0 & S\end{array}\right)$ and $X$ by $\left(\begin{array}{ll}X & 0 \\ 0 & 0\end{array}\right)$.
The following outcome is an implication of Theorems 2.3, 2.9, and Corollary 2.6, resulting in:
Corollary 2.10. Let $T, S, X \in M_{\kappa}(\mathbb{C})$ with $T, S$ positive definite, $\kappa \in[0,1]$ and $\psi(\vartheta, \kappa)$ and $\phi(\vartheta, \kappa)$ are same as taken in Theorem (2.3) and (2.9) respectively. Then

$$
\psi(0, \kappa) \leq \frac{1}{2} \phi(0, \kappa) \leq \psi(\vartheta, \kappa)
$$

for $\vartheta \in[1 / 2, \infty)$, or equivalently, for any unitarily invariant norm $\|\cdot\|$ and $t \in(-2,2]$,

$$
\left\|\left|T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}\right|\right\| \leq \frac{1}{2}\left\|\left|T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}+T^{1-\kappa} X S^{\kappa}\right|\right\| \leq \frac{1}{t+2}\left\|\mid T X+X S+t T^{\kappa} X S^{1-\kappa}\right\|
$$

Remark 2.11. (i) It's worth noting that the corollary mentioned earlier (2.5) represents one of the potential enhancements to an inequality introduced by Kaur and Singh in their work (see [Kaur and Singh, 2011, Corollary 2.4]).
(ii) Take note that when we set $\kappa$ to the value of one-third (i.e., $\kappa=\frac{1}{3}$ ), it is evident that we arrive at the outcome outlined in Theorem 2.10 in Kaur and Singh [2011]. This implies that our finding constitutes a broader and more generalized version of their result.

# 3 Sharpening of the Heinz inequalities and its reverses with the Kantorovich Constant 

In this section, we make a refinement of Heinz inequality with the Kantorovich constant.

Lemma 3.1. Let $\rho, \sigma>0$ and $0 \leq \nu<\kappa \leq 1$. Then

$$
r\left(\sqrt{\rho_{\kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma}-\sqrt{\sigma}\right)^{2}+K(\sqrt{h}, 2)^{r^{\prime}} \rho_{\kappa \nu}^{\kappa} \sigma \leq \nu \rho+(1-\nu) \sigma-\left(\frac{\nu}{\kappa}\right)\left(\rho \nabla_{\kappa} \sigma-\rho_{\kappa}^{\kappa} \sigma\right)
$$

# 4 New operator versions of Heinz-type inequalities 

Let $\mathcal{H}$ represent a complex Hilbert space, and $\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$ denote the $C^{*}$-algebra comprising all bounded linear operators on $\mathcal{H}$. An operator $T \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$ is considered positive if $\langle T x, x\rangle \geq 0$ holds true for every $x \in \mathcal{H}$. We express this as $T \geq 0$. Now, let $T$ and $S$ be two positive operators in $\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$, and $\kappa$ take on values in the interval $[0,1]$. The $\kappa$-weighted arithmetic mean of $T$ and $S$, denoted as $T \nabla_{\kappa} S$, is defined as:

$$
T \nabla_{\kappa} S=(1-\kappa) T+\kappa S
$$

When $T$ is invertible, the $\kappa$-geometric mean of $T$ and $S$, represented as $T_{\# \kappa}^{a} S$, is defined as:

$$
T_{\# \kappa}^{a} S=T^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(T^{-\frac{1}{2}} S T^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\kappa} T^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

In the case where $\kappa=\frac{1}{2}$, we can simplify the notation to $T \nabla S$ and $T_{\#}^{a} S$ to refer to the $\kappa$-weighted arithmetic mean and the $\kappa$-geometric mean, respectively. It is well-known that for positive invertible operators $T$ and $S$, the following inequality holds:

$$
T_{\# \kappa}^{a} S \leq T \nabla_{\kappa} S, \quad \kappa \in[0,1]
$$

Additionally, we define the operator version of the Heinz mean as $H_{\kappa}(T, S)$ :

$$
H_{\kappa}(T, S)=\frac{T_{\# \kappa}^{a} S+T_{\# 1-\kappa}^{a} S}{2}
$$

for the case where $T$ and $S$ are positive invertible operators and $\kappa \in[0,1]$.

Theorem 5.9. Let $T_{i} \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})(i=1, \cdots, n)$ be positive semi-definite. If $0 \leq \vartheta_{i} \leq 1(i=1, \cdots, n)$ with $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \vartheta_{i}=1$, then

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{tr}\left(\vartheta_{k} T_{k}\right) \geq \operatorname{tr}\left|\prod_{k=1}^{n} T_{k}^{\vartheta_{k}}\right|+r\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)-n \sqrt[n]{\prod_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)}\right)
$$

where $r=\min \left\{\vartheta_{k}: k=1, \cdots, n\right\}$.
Proof. By inequality (36), we have

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right) \geq \prod_{k=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)^{\vartheta_{k}}+r\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)-n \sqrt[n]{\prod_{k=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)}\right)
$$

for $j=1, \cdots, n$. Thus, by Lemma 5.2 and the generalized Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{tr}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} T_{k}\right) & =\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)=\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} \sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right) \\
& \geq \sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{1}^{\vartheta_{1}}\right) \cdots s_{j}\left(T_{k}^{\vartheta_{n}}\right) \\
& +r\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)-n \sum_{j=1}^{n} \sqrt[n]{\prod_{k=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{n}\right)}\right) \\
& \geq \sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{1}^{\vartheta_{1}} \cdots T_{n}^{\vartheta_{n}}\right) \\
& +r\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)-n \sqrt[n]{\prod_{k=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)}\right) \\
& \geq \operatorname{tr}\left|T_{1}^{\vartheta_{1}} \cdots T_{n}^{\vartheta_{n}}\right|+r\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)-n \sqrt[n]{\prod_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $r=\min \left\{\vartheta_{k}: k=1, \cdots, n\right\}$.

Our Theorem 5.9 entils the following trace norm

$$
\left\|\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} T_{k}\right\|_{1} \geq\left\|\prod_{k=1}^{n} T_{k}^{\vartheta_{k}}\right\|_{1}+r\left(\left\|\sum_{k=1}^{n} T_{k}\right\|_{1}-n \sqrt[n]{\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left\|T_{k}\right\|_{1}}\right)
$$

where $r=\min \left\{\vartheta_{k}: k=1, \cdots, n\right\}$.
Theorem 5.10. Let $T_{i} \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})(i=1, \cdots, n)$ be positive definite. If $0 \leq \vartheta_{i} \leq 1(i=1, \cdots, n)$ with $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \vartheta_{i}=1$, then

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} T_{k}\right) \geq \prod_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{det}\left(T_{k}^{\vartheta_{k}}\right)+r\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} T_{k}\right)-n \sqrt[n]{\prod_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{det}\left(T_{k}\right)}\right)
$$

where $r=\min \left\{\vartheta_{k}: k=1, \cdots, n\right\}$.
To prove Theorem 5.10, we need the following lemma.
Lemma 5.11 (R.A. Horn [1985]). Let $T, S \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ be positive definite. Then we have

$$
\operatorname{det}(T+S)^{\frac{1}{n}} \geq \operatorname{det}(T)^{\frac{1}{n}}+\operatorname{det}(S)^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

Proof of Theorem 5.10. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{det}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} T_{k}\right) & =\left[\operatorname{det}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} T_{k}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}\right]^{n} \\
& \geq\left[\sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{det}\left(\vartheta_{k} T_{k}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}\right]^{n} \quad \text { (by Lemma 5.11) } \\
& \geq\left[\sum_{k=1}^{n} \vartheta_{k} \operatorname{det}\left(T_{k}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}\right]^{n} \\
& \geq\left[\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\left(T_{k}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}\right)^{\vartheta_{k}}\right]^{n}+r^{n}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{det}\left(T_{k}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}-n \sqrt[n]{\operatorname{det} \prod_{k=1}^{n} T_{k}}\right) \\
& =\prod_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{det}\left(T_{k}^{\vartheta_{k}}\right)+r^{n}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{det}\left(T_{k}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}-n \sqrt[n]{\operatorname{det} \prod_{k=1}^{n} T_{k}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma 5.12 (Pavić [2015]). Let $\gamma_{1}, \gamma_{2}, \cdots, \gamma_{n}$ be a set of non-negative real numbers constrained by $\sum_{k=1}^{j} \gamma_{k}=\Gamma_{j}$. If $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \cdots, \omega_{n}$ are positive real numbers, then

$$
\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} \omega_{k}+\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} \omega_{k}\right)^{2}} \geq\left[\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\omega_{k}+\sqrt{1+\omega_{k}^{2}}\right)^{\gamma_{k}}\right]^{\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}}}
$$

holds.
Theorem 5.13. Let $T_{1}, \cdots, T_{k} \in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ be positive define and let $\gamma_{1}, \gamma_{2}, \cdots, \gamma_{n}$ be a set of non-negative real numbers such that $\sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k}=\Gamma_{n}$. Then

$$
\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)+\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)\right)^{2}} \geq \prod_{k=1}^{n}\left[\operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)+\sqrt{1+\operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}^{2}\right)}\right]^{\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}}}
$$

Proof. By inequality (41), we have

$$
\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)+\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)\right)^{2}} \geq\left[\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)+\sqrt{1+s_{j}^{2}\left(T_{k}\right)}\right)^{\gamma_{k}}\right]^{\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}}}
$$

for all $j=1, \cdots, n$. Hence we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} \sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right) & +\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} \sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)\right)^{2}} \\
& \geq\left[\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}\left(T_{k}\right)+\sqrt{1+\sum_{j=1}^{n} s_{j}^{2}\left(T_{k}\right)}\right)^{\gamma_{k}}\right]^{\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Consequently,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{tr}\left(\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} T_{k}\right) & +\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)\right)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)+\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)\right)^{2}} \\
& \geq\left[\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}\right)+\sqrt{1+\sum_{j=1}^{n} \operatorname{tr}\left(T_{k}^{2}\right)}\right)^{\gamma_{k}}\right]^{\frac{1}{\Gamma_{n}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

# 6 Conclusion and Future Work 

In conclusion, this paper has embarked on an extensive investigation into the domain of matrix means interpolation and comparison. A key aspect of this research has been the expansion of the parameter $\vartheta$ from the closed interval $[0,1]$ to encompass the entire positive real line, represented as $\mathbb{R}^{+}$. This extension has allowed us to explore a broader spectrum of mathematical relationships and properties within this framework.
Furthermore, our exploration has led to the development of various novel results related to Heinz means. We have introduced scalar variants of Heinz inequalities, leveraging Kantorovich's constant, and have extended these inequalities to the operator realm. This expansion not only deepens our understanding of Heinz means but also opens up new avenues for applications in diverse mathematical contexts.
Lastly, we have presented refined Young's type inequalities specifically tailored for traces, determinants, and norms of positive semi-definite matrices. These refined inequalities are expected to find utility in various matrix analysis and linear algebra problems, enhancing our ability to derive meaningful conclusions and insights from the study of positive semi-definite matrices.
As for future work, there are several intriguing directions to consider. Firstly, it may be valuable to explore further extensions of the parameter space beyond $\mathbb{R}^{+}$and investigate the implications of such extensions on matrix means and related inequalities. Additionally, the applicability of the developed results in practical fields such as physics, engineering, and data science warrants investigation. Finally, refining and expanding upon the presented inequalities could lead to even more powerful tools for matrix analysis and optimization, offering new insights and solutions to complex problems in mathematics and its applications.
